Award.AwardTitle: BRAIN: EAGER: Memory Reactivation in Neural Circuits Over Long, Continuous Timescales
Award.AbstractNarration:
Memories of facts and experiences take time to be stored robustly in the brain. Understanding of the underlying mechanisms would not only yield insight into a fundamental ability found in all animals, but also allow for the optimization of learning and memory in healthy individuals as well as interventions in humans with compromised memory. Many current hypotheses of memory posit the importance of "replay" within ensembles of neurons in the brain. The idea is that in periods of quiescence or sleep, neurons in the hippocampus, a key brain structure for memory, re-excite the patterns of activity that occurred during the original learning/experience. This neural replay of the original activity patterns enables distributed cortical regions to form robust, lasting interconnections and thereby support memory. In rats learning to navigate mazes, the signals of dozens of individual hippocampal neurons can be accessed simultaneously. In this project, neural recording, computational, and statistical tools are developed and tested to observe neuronal activity in the hippocampus of rats over long periods of time-- periods that include repeated active learning and quiescence/sleep episodes-- and address fundamental questions about replay and how individual neurons participate in replay/learning over time. The algorithms developed in this project are shared widely through on-line media. The data collected contribute to instructional material used in interdisciplinary graduate training programs and courses focused on neural signal processing.

In this project, new neural recording technology and novel and computational analysis techniques are used to acquire and interpret week-long continuous recordings of hippocampal activity while an animal learns a novel task. The result is the first ever qualitative and quantitative assessment of replay over a period of this length. The resulting data have the potential to yield great insight into how changes in patterns of neural activity at the scales of milliseconds (replay) interact with changes at the scales of hours (circadian) and days (learning). The algorithms developed, which are shared through a public on-line site, may be foundational to a new experimental paradigm where neurons are recorded continuously over time. A particularly valuable outcome of the project are novel algorithms for automatically isolating the signals of individual neurons from each other, and tracking slow changes to their signatures over time. Additionally, a new latent-variable model technique for quantifying how individual replay events compare with the patterns exhibited during learning enables the statistics of replay variability to be assessed. The impacts of this work have the potential to be broad, from techniques that revolutionize systems neuroscience to data that underpins new models of learning and memory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Learning is complex, involving the entire brain, from primary sensory to motor output systems. Understanding of the underlying mechanisms would not only yield insight into a fundamental ability found in all animals, but also allow for the optimization of learning and memory in healthy individuals as well as interventions in humans with compromised memory. In this project, we developed new technologies – embedded systems and algorithms – to enable the study of the neural bases of learning continuously across extended periods of time.

Memories of facts and experiences take time to be stored (consolidated) robustly in the brain. One of the primary mechanisms for this memory consolidation process is believed to be a phenomenon known as “replay”, during which the brain subconsciously repeats (reactivates) neural activity corresponding to an earlier event or experience. These replay bouts happen repeatedly, at compressed timescales (each lasting much less than a second), and mostly during periods of inactivity. However, most of what we know and understand about replay has been discovered or observed during relatively short periods (no more than a few hours) following experiments. In this project, neural recording, computational, and statistical tools were developed and tested to observe neuronal activity over long periods of time – periods that included repeated active learning and quiescence/sleep episodes across multiple days – all of which will help to address fundamental questions about replay and how individual neurons participate in replay/learning over time.

Indeed, multiple batches of week-long data have now been collected (which will be made freely available online following some initial preprocessing), and the resulting data have the potential to yield great insight into how changes in patterns of neural activity at the scales of milliseconds (replay) interact with changes at the scales of hours (circadian) and days (learning). Somewhat tangentially, it was found that neural reactivation of a noxious event/experience could inform a subject against taking a particular action – the first time that such a clear divergence was shown between neural reactivation and subsequent behavior.

Furthermore, a new latent-variable model technique was developed, which can help researchers to quantify how individual replay events compare with the patterns exhibited during learning, as well as for statistics of replay variability to be assessed. This new latent-variable approach to replay detection is complementary to existing approaches, in that it can detect likely replay events that were not possible to detect before, opening up the possibility to study replay in a 

much broader class of experiments and modalities. We have also used this technique to demonstrate that neural activity during replay bouts contain sufficient information to reconstruct high fidelity models of the associated experiences.

To further support our and others’ efforts into understanding the mechanisms underlying learning and memory, an open-source module was developed for the real-time detection of replay-like activity (sharp wave ripples in particular). In doing so, we can modulate the neural activity around these events to study their causal relationship with learning more closely.

Finally, powerful software tools (written in Python) for the analysis of electrophysiology data and replay data in particular have been developed, and these have also been made freely available online.

This project has allowed us to develop and refine many of the components needed for an in-depth study of neural reactivation over long continuous timescales, and we expect the impacts of this work to be broad, ranging from techniques that revolutionize systems neuroscience to data that underpins new models of learning and memory.
